reviewText: The movie starts with a stockbroker working in Boston. Andrew. Andrew looks to be 35 or so. I could not get over how mature and stock brokerish he seemed. The problem, Andrew has gotten himself involved with the mob and when it appears that one of Andrew's friends is going to go to the Feds... the friend is killed and Andrew is put into protective custody.  Alas, the protection is not that good and after almost getting killed himself.. Andrew runs and escapes by the skin of his teeth. As a child this scene thrilled me because it is set in South Station in Boston. Now I walk through it every day.Andrew decides to visit his aunt (I believe in North Carolina) on the way though, he drastically changes his appearance. Making him look very young. When he goes to visit his aunt at work, he is mistaken for a student and decides to go with it. After all who would ever look for him as a high school student. Fortunately Jon Cryer can pull this off. The plan, live with his aunt and cousin and be a high school student for a while. He decides not to tell his aunt (presumably to protect her) and crash with his cousin.Of course, best laid plans. Despite himself he shows up a few teachers and impresses some classmates who want him to run for student office. Then, he falls in love with a 16 year old classmate. Of course. And in the end the mobsters do find him and things get hairy.This movie would not have been as good without Jon Cryer. He made me believe the entire thing even that he was a 32 year old stockbroker walking around school looking like a punk rocker. I enjoyed him doing things he hadn't done in years (such as roller skating) and truly not wanting to fall for the lovely Ryan (the aforementioned 16 year old girl).Pick it up.

reviewText: Once upon a time there were some very interesting movies made. This was during the 1980s. Some directors had some interesting ideas about showing how high school can have quirky moments and be educational sometimes but also give life lessons that will help down the road. Even the teachers have political viewpoints, not just parents. Maybe not anymore. After all that wouldn't be politically correct any more to talk about that in class.I feel sorry for students today, so many things are not allowed I don't know how they can learn anything about life and having a personality. Well back to this movie. It is Jon Cryer's best from all his movies that I have seen. Funny and suspenseful with some love thrown in for romantics. Cryer is a stock broker, Andrew Morenski, that finds himself on the run from hitmen. He hides out with a nephew and finds that being high school student, Max Hauser, is a good cover. Cryer is excellent and the rest the supporting cast are great as well. Any fan of movies like "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" and "The Breakfast Club" will probably love it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love and miss the 80’s and how they did high school movies.  Looking back today they all look like 20 something’s trying to be teens again but that is what made this one in my mind stick out.  I liked the thought of going back to school with a bit of knowledge about how the world really works, a perspective you can’t get when you haven’t been there.  This is one of those movies I remember seeing on a weekend, missed the beginning but watched the rest and said “I should find that some day”.  This movie looks good on the shelf with all the other 80’s flicks I have since rounded up.  It is a good and solid addition if you have a similar collection.
summary: Everyone in High School was 20+ in the 80's weren’t they?

reviewText: Ever wonder what it would be like to go back to high school as an adult? That is what Jon Cryer's (also in Pretty in Pink, great movie) character has to do to hide out from some people who are trying to kill him. He changes from a bearded broker in the big city to a clean shaven, t-shirt wearing "kid" in a different town, staying with his cousin and even fooling his aunt (she doesn't know it's him!) There is a nice mix of comedy, romance, and action in this movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hiding Out has been hiding out from the funny 80's teen flicks. It has been lost in between the Brat Pack and John Hughes finest, but it is just as corny/funny as the rest of them. Jon Cryer plays Andrew a stockbroker running for his life from the mob and the feds who are attempting to protect him. After narrowly escaping from the Mob, Andrew assumes a new identity in a new town. What is not planned ahead is the fact that he will be a high-schooler again.The interactions with teachers, fellow students, love interests, and his dorky cousin Patrick make this movie quality for the genre it belongs in.Good soundtrack and memorable quotes round out this lost flick.

reviewText: I know what you must be thinking: what the h*ll is he talking about?  I'm not talking about the movie in general, which is OK, but rather a specific scene in which a teacher tries to brainwash kids into thinking Nixon was a great president.  Come ON.  Have you ever known a teacher like that?  Of course not.  The brainwashing from high school teachers comes from the other side of the political spectrum.  That scene is a good example of the insidious left-ness of Hollywood.Anyhow, watch the movie, it's pretty entertaining, but be alert for covert political messages.
summary: Good example of mass media leftism

reviewText: Hiding Out is an absolutely fabulous 80's classic teen comedy. The premise of a witness hiding from a mobster has been done before, but not this well. John Cryer is a supurb actor, and this film was made so much more enjoyable because Mr. Cryer seemed to be having such a good time with this story that landed him in a high school, trying to not only pass as a kid, but survive teenage angst all over again along with his young cousin.The story is not only humorous, but suspenseful, and I enjoyed every moment of it.
summary: Where has this movie been hiding out?

reviewText: I was really impressed with the HBO to Video now DVD.  So hidden has this movie been from the spotlight that it I am impressed at how little press it has ever gotten.  I own the video and will some day buy the DVD.This movie takes you from the Boston Stock market and trainyards to an small outlying city where John Cryer hides out at his cousins high school.  This is a great story with a rather plausible plot.  There are some very funny scenes when Cryer, playing Max, has to explain why he knows so much for a high school senior.As he faces up to the challenges of 'teen age' he becomes more liked by his 'peers' and gets volunteered to the be the Sr. Class President.He is hiding out because he is a witness in a case against a mobster for trading issues that involved Cryer (Andrew Morenski) and his team.  One of his associates gets bumped off by a hitman and Morenski has to run.  And the hitman is relentless in his pursuit of Morenski.There are some very touching scenes, a little romance and really an introduction to a talented Annabeth Gish.  Cryer gets in the middle of all the high school antics and frustrations.It is an amazing comparison between an adult who has become of age and facing death, but renewing his life as a 'youth.'As a comedy I rate it a 5 out of 5.As a romance I rate it a 4 out of 5.As an action thriller I rate it a 4.5 out of 5.There is a little language, some blood, a lot of action and a great story.  Add this little gem to your DVD library and enjoy it from time to time with family and friends.  So many will wonder where the movie came from and thank you for introducing them to it.
summary: How Can You Not Like This Movie?  Name from a Coffee Can?

reviewText: Andrew Morenski (Jon Cryer) is a Wall Street broker in his prime living the good life and making the nice money.  That is until the FBI wants him to testify against a mob figure regarding a bogus financial deal.  It seems okay until hit men enter the picture and the government protection lets him down.  Plan B though finds him hiding out in suburbia with his aunt and cousin and eventually leads him to hiding out back in his cousin's high school of all places.  That can't be all bad right?Wrong.  Now it's time for the best laid plans to go right out the window in the funniest ways ever.  Maxwell Hauser (nothing like getting your alias from a coffee can) becomes the oldest student ever in high school and he just can't get a break.  For someone who's trying to keep a low profile, Maxwell turns out to be an instant success.  He hits it off with his cousin's friends who want him to run for student body president. Then there are the obnoxious teachers who he happens to be smarter than and he shows them up.  And finally, he has to experience teen dating and romance all over again without falling flat on his face.  Did I mention he also has to counsel his nerdy cousin on half a dozen different things?  Oh, and this while always trying to avoid mafia assassins.  High School goes haywire, that's good fun.The acting in `Hiding Out' is really good and with Jon Cryer being the focal character, he does a great job.  Annabeth Gish was good too as his love interest and I couldn't believe I didn't see her in anything else until season nine of the X-Files.  Go figure. As far as the plot goes, it's a solid story with good doses of humor throughout and an exciting ending.  If you're a fan of 80's movies like Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Sixteen Candles, and The Breakfast Club, you'll get a kick out this too.  This is recommended viewing.
summary: Hiding Out - a nostalgic laugh fest from the 80's

reviewText: The 80s was a decade of waste . . . money was thrown around like it grew on trees. . . and the movie industry is one of the easiest ways to see this. This movie was a joke. It was supposed to be a movie about an adult who has to go into the witness protection program (how unique) because he is involved with the mob somehow (never really got that part . . . something about stock trading) and they are out to kill all the witnesses before the trial--him being one. So they "age" Jon Cryer in this creepy child molester look . . . disguise . . . like we don't know it is Jon Cryer. Anyway, how the guy looks is just creepy weird . . . the only other worse disguise trick in a movie that I have seen is "Color of Night" where this female actress dresses up from the get-to of her introduction to the audience as a man only for the surprise reveal at the end that she is actually a woman--NO WAY!!! Yes Way. Then how the character sets out on the run after the mob blows away his FBI protectors is just lazy writing. Anyway this gives the unimaginative writers the chance to show Cryer as a young guy, Cryer shedding his 'disguise" so he can fit in at a high school where he hides out. To fill the voids and make movie goers think they are watching a movie and not a 30 minute sitcom they just show for no reason the main character's cousin learning to drive with all the cheesy trashcan fender benders and the nervous driver's ed instructor etc. This movie was just a reason to burn money . . . no plot, no writing, no acting. Jon Cryer looked creepy in this movie even when not in his "disguise" at the beginning. He has this reddish brown eyed look that made him look like a vampire. This fangs get exposed several times too. I mean I don't have anything bad to say about Cryer as I really don't know his work or anything about his image that Hollywood puts forth for him. But he looks eerie here and making him look that way doesn't fit into the "plot" so I have to assume it just was, which is even eerier.
summary: another 80s movie made for waste and not art

reviewText: I'm a big fan of 80's movies.  Anytime I watch one of these classic films,  it takes me back to high school when my friends and I would walk to the movies and just have mad fun.  Now having said that,  I highly recommend this movie for anyone young or old.  Does Jon Cryer ever age?  Yes,  the actor who portrays Alan Harper stars in this movie as a stockbroker who is on a mobsters hit list.  Having gone into witness protection as a student who calls himself, Maxwell Hauser (yep, he looks at a coffee can and comes up with that name), Cryer transforms himself from a bearded wall street yuppie,  to a multicolored haired, clean shaven 18 year old.  A must see.....
